flags.evidence:
CPI is not downloaded from BLS/FRED or another documented source; it is manually constructed via piecewise linear formulas by year/month. This is synthetic data generation (not random, but fabricated/approximated) that directly affects the deflation of minimum wages (real_mw) used in estimation. The manuscript states CPI-U deflation using standard practice, implying official CPI-U values, not an ad-hoc constructed series.: cpi_data <- tibble(
  year = rep(2005:2023, each = 12),
  month = rep(1:12, 19)
) %>%
  mutate(
    cpi = case_when(
      year == 2005 ~ 191.0 + (month - 1) * 0.4,
      year == 2006 ~ 198.3 + (month - 1) * 0.3,
      ...
      year == 2023 ~ 299.2 + (month - 1) * 0.3,
      TRUE ~ 260
    )
  )

The script creates additional outcome variables (BA, HBA, WBA) as arbitrary deterministic fractions of establishment counts and then expands annual data to monthly via `crossing(month = 1:12)`. These variables look like 'Business Applications' series (typical Census BFS terminology) but are not fetched from any BFS source; they are synthetic proxies. This is problematic because other scripts (04_robustness.R, 06_tables.R) treat BA/HBA/WBA as real outcomes and run regressions on them.: bfs_data <- qcew_panel %>%
  ...
  crossing(month = 1:12) %>%
  mutate(
    BA = round(establishments / 12),
    HBA = round(BA * 0.3),
    WBA = round(BA * 0.25)
  )

State minimum wage histories are hard-coded as a large manual table rather than sourced from an external file/API. While the manuscript says minimum wage data are compiled from DOL and state records (which can justify manual compilation), the code provides no citations, checks, or reproducible provenance for these values, and the table is incomplete (only a subset of states appear). This materially affects treatment assignment and real MW levels.: state_mw_changes <- tribble(
  ~state_abbr, ~effective_date, ~state_mw,
  # California
  "CA", "2004-01-01", 6.75, "CA", "2007-01-01", 7.50, ...
  ...
)

Minimum wage data are not fetched or validated against an external data source; they are embedded in code. Additionally, many states are absent from `state_mw_changes`. For absent states, the code later imputes `state_mw = federal_mw` (see below), which can incorrectly classify states that had above-federal minimum wages but are missing from the hard-coded list.: state_mw_changes <- tribble(
  ~state_abbr, ~effective_date, ~state_mw,
  ...
)

For any state-month not matched to a record in the hard-coded `state_mw_changes`, the code sets the state minimum wage equal to the federal minimum wage. If the `state_mw_changes` table is incomplete (it appears to include only selected states), this transform silently forces many states to be treated as never-above-federal, biasing treatment assignment and attenuating estimates toward zero.: mw_panel <- all_state_months %>%
  left_join(mw_panel %>% select(state_abbr, year, month, state_mw), by = c("state_abbr", "year", "month")) %>%
  mutate(
    state_mw = if_else(is.na(state_mw), federal_mw, state_mw),
    effective_mw = pmax(state_mw, federal_mw),
    above_federal = effective_mw > federal_mw
  )

The code labels `establishments = max(BA)` as the annual establishment count, but `BA` was earlier defined as `round(establishments/12)` after expanding annual data to months. This makes the analysis outcome approximately 1/12 of the true annual establishment count. The manuscript claims CBP annual establishment counts at the state-year level; this implementation does not match that description and changes the scale/interpretation of the dependent variable.: bfs_annual <- bfs_data %>%
  group_by(state_abbr, state_fips, year) %>%
  summarize(
    establishments = max(BA, na.rm = TRUE),  # Annual establishment count
    .groups = "drop"
  )

The manuscript’s outcome is CBP establishment counts (annual), but this table script is written for monthly 'Business Applications' style outcomes (BA/HBA/WBA). Those variables are not described in the manuscript and (in this repository) are constructed as arbitrary transformations of establishment counts rather than fetched BFS series. This suggests the codebase may be partially repurposed from a different project, risking inconsistent reporting and confusion about what outcomes were actually analyzed.: summary_outcomes <- analysis_panel %>%
  summarize(
    `Business Applications` = mean(BA, na.rm = TRUE),
    `High-Propensity Applications` = mean(HBA, na.rm = TRUE),
    `Applications w/ Planned Wages` = mean(WBA, na.rm = TRUE)
  )

Robustness code runs placebo and robustness regressions on `log_BA` with year-month fixed effects (`ym_fe`), implying a monthly panel of business applications. The main manuscript describes an annual state-year panel of establishment counts (2012–2021). This mismatch undermines the traceability of robustness claims in the paper (e.g., placebo tests, alternative FE) to the stated empirical design.: placebo_continuous <- feols(
  log_BA ~ log_real_mw_lead12 | state_fe + ym_fe,
  data = placebo_data,
  cluster = ~state_abbr
)

summary.executive_summary: The data pipeline hard-codes and fabricates key inputs instead of downloading them from documented sources: CPI is manually constructed with ad hoc, piecewise month-to-month formulas rather than being fetched from BLS/FRED, leaving inflation adjustment without verifiable provenance. It also manufactures additional outcome variables (BA/HBA/WBA) as deterministic fractions of establishment counts and converts annual figures to monthly by mechanically repeating them across 12 months, creating synthetic time-series variation. Minimum-wage values are embedded in an incomplete state change table, and any unmatched state-month is defaulted to the federal minimum wage, which can systematically misstate state policies and bias results.
